urls.title: Cellular therapy: Great promise, but at what cost?
urls.description: The introduction of chimeric antigen receptor T cell (CAR-T) therapy has been transformative in hematological malignancies. In the US, there are now 6 FDA-approved products across 5 malignancies; acute lymphoblastic leukemia, diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL), follicular lymphoma, mantle cell lymphoma, and multiple myeloma. These are highly potent treatments that are effective in patients that are highly pretreated and chemo-refractory and are likely curative in some cases. However, despite the fact that the first commercial CAR-T product (axicabtagene ciloleucel) received an FDA approval in October 2017, access to CAR-T remains challenging for myriad reasons including, but not limited to, expertise, infrastructure for apheresis and administration, manufacturing capacity, and cost.

urls.title: Methods of optimizing transplantation in MDS
urls.description: Ryotaro Nakamura, MD, City of Hope, Duarte, CA, discusses various methods that may be used to optimize transplantation in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), such as improving patient health and donor options, optimizing pre- and post-transplant therapy, and improving geriatric assessments for patients. This interview took place at the Tenth Annual Meeting of the Society of Hematologic Oncology (SOHO) held in Houston, TX. These works are owned by Magdalen Medical Publishing (MMP) and are protected by copyright laws and treaties around the world. All rights are reserved.

urls.title: Hematology and Pregnancy: We Can Do Better | ASH News Daily | American Society of Hematology
urls.description: Dr. Amanda Blackmon (@mlblack1_b) returns this year after serving as a Junior Author in 2021. Originally from Gaithersburg, Maryland, she attended the University of Maryland for undergrad, earned her MS at Georgetown University, and attended medical school at the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine in Philadelphia. After her residency at Pennsylvania Hospital, Dr. Blackmon headed west for fellowships at University of California Irvine, and City of Hope National Medical Center in Duarte. She is

I just want to make a few things clear:
 
The Holocaust happened.

@matthew_mei @BijoyTelivala Dr. Mei will soon publish his research work on why sleep is actually optional for health care providers-- you are seriously one of the hardest-working people I've ever seen.  What's wrong with being on-call every other day?  you miss 50% of the cases.
@BijoyTelivala I do a lot of research and am on pace for >6000 RVU this year.

Can we agree that all #oncologist don’t wanna do research 🔬 

Majority like to see pt and teach 

If everyone was in research and seeing pt 1/2 day a week , how will all of the people who need help be ever seen or taken care of 

#MedTwitter

@uroosaibrahim Difficult sitch. The CART should perform well against the marrow MRD so less worried about systemic bridging, but since you haven’t been able to fully control CNS dz with IT, I’d favor HD-MTX+/-IDAC (unless recently failed HD-MTX) in which case I’d do IDAC+/-Etop or CNS XRT.
@JillLykon Why is that?

ALL CAR T bridging q: 65 F, ph+ ALL, with frank CNS relapse & systemic molecular relapse only (on bosutinib with persistent low level bcr-abl, intolerant/unresponsive to other TKIs/asciminib), pre-leukapheresis IT x 4 (CD19+ blasts 47% > 9%). Recommend bridging therapy with:

@MarceloBellesso No more MTx ✋🏻 R-ICE f/b Thiotepa ASCT ?

What are your views on this @BijoyTelivala @Prasshmehta @GuiperiniMD @matthew_mei

The burnout epidemic CANNOT be resolved with self care. It is job related. Hospital executives must improve working conditions : reduce template size, number of clicks in EHR, increase time with patients, appoint leaders who like and value clinical care. https://t.co/RD6hxt22VS
@mattnightingale Good thing the med student on emergency stroke call at the hospital in Detroit this month for when they blow an aneurysm is...gay as fuck...

@GomezDLeonMD @AaronGoodman33 @matthew_mei @MediHumdani @Lymphoma_Doc @BijoyTelivala @WolverHeme @GuiperiniMD @hematologo @AnnaSureda5 @graham74GC We have combined many of the ideas others have suggested in an AYA patient who was refractory to ICE. Gemcitabine, asparaginase, platinum (GELOX) and added dex. Pt achieved a CR and went to allo. Now 3.5 years post allo still in CR. Only N=1 though @annabrown915 @VictoriaNachar
